abstract.text: Tracks events that match the specified mask using the specified tracking handler until the tracking handler explicitly terminates tracking.

inlineContent.text: The maximum time interval the system waits for an event before passing
A block that is called to track the events. The block takes the following parameters:
A Boolean value that indicates when tracking should stop.
You can use this method in a tracking loop to get pressure events when you add
to the event mask. This method returns when tracking terminates.

Each event is removed from the event queue and then passed to the tracking handler. If a matching event does not exist in the event queue, the main thread blocks in the specified runloop mode until an event of the requested type is received or the specified timeout expires. If the timeout expires, the tracking handler is called with a
event (a negative timeout is interpreted as
to prevent timing out. Tracking continues until you set

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An object that contains information about an input action, such as a mouse click or a key press.
Constants that you use to filter out specific event types from the stream of incoming events.
A mask for pressure-change events.
The longest time duration possible.
A window that an app displays on the screen.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the window accepts mouse-moved events.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the window is transparent to mouse events.
The current location of the pointer reckoned in the window’s base coordinate system, regardless of the current event being handled or of any events pending.
Returns the next event matching a given mask.
Starts a window drag based on the specified mouse-down event.
Tracks events that match the specified mask using the specified tracking handler until the tracking handler explicitly terminates tracking.
Returns the number of the frontmost window that would be hit by a mouse-down at the specified screen location.
A true value.
Type to represent a Boolean value.
Modes that a run loop operates in.
A number of seconds.
The programmatic interface to objects that manage input sources.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
